-yoga, kuvera-parbeśa, kiṁstughna-muhūrtta, kanyā-rāśi,

kunaṁ punyeni yogya diAnumodanā Oleḥ sakaprajā di bhūmi malāyu, brāhmaṇa kṣatriya vaiśya sūdra, Ācāryyopāddhyāya, śrī mahārāja śrīmat· tribhuvanarājamaulivarmmadeva pramukha,

app.note: With viśākhā-nakṣatra, the expected devatā is Śakrāgni, but this appears not to have been written.
The taling of yoga, already noted at the end of line 1, is repeated redundantly at the start if line 2.
Probably due to inadvertence, omits this word.

It seems certain that no subscript vowel marker ū is engraved below the y, by contrast with the preceding word bhūmi. Although we cannot exclude that bhūmi malāya was intended, because Adityawarman's inscriptions (Rambahan, Gudam I) refer to the royal capital being called Malayapura; nevertheless, the expression bhūmi malayu is attested in the Deśavaraṇana ​(13.2 yekādinyaṅ vatək bhūmi malayu), and it seems hard to believe that any other expression was intended here.

div.p: Hail! Elapsed Śaka year 1208, month of Bhādravāda, initial tithi of the waxing fortnight, Mavulu, Vāge, Thursday i.e., 1286-08-22, wuku Maḍaṅkuṅan, the grahacāra in the south-west, lunar mansion Viśākha, deity Śakra, the maṇḍala being , the conjunction Śubha, the regent of the astronomical node Kuvera, the muhūrta Kiṅstughna, the zodiac sign Virgo.

This is when the holy deity Ārya-Amoghapāśalokeśvara with fourteen selves (?) together with the seven jewels was brought from Javanese soil to Svarṇabhūmi i.e., Sumatra and installed at Dharmāśraya, as akan the meritorious work puṇya of Śrī Viśvarūpakumāra. Because ? prakāranaṅThe meaning and correct division into words of prakāranaṅ remain elusive. The following interpretations may also be considered: The matter prakāra, which ? naṅ was ordered; As for prakāra the ones who ? naṅ were ordered. it was ordered by His Majesty the Overlord of Great Kings, Śrī Kr̥tanagara Vikramadharmmottuṅgadeva, the holy deity was accompanied by the lord Great Minister dyah Advayabrahma, the Lord of Sirikan dyah Sugatabrahma, with the official of Payānan, haṅ Dīpaṅkaradāsa, and the lord of Dəmuṅ pu Vīra.

As for kunaṅ this meritorious work, it deserves the assent of all inhabitants of Malay soil, whether Brahmins, Kṣatriyas, Vaiśyas or Śūdras, and first of all Śrī Viśvarūpakumāra's masters and preceptors, as well as the Great King, the illustrious śrīmat Tribhuvanarājamaulivarmadeva.Note the dedication formula in Kertanagara's Amoghapāśa plaques, of which no less than five are known, all entirely formulated in Sanskrit (, ), which use partly similar phraseology and suggest that Tribhuvanarājamaulivarmadeva was Viśvarūpakumāra's father.
Thanks to this merit may I attain Buddhahood and help all creatures cross the deep sea of existences!
The language is a form of Old Malay with more than averga inflitration of Old Javanese elements, such as the words muaṅ and kunaṅ.

First edited by Krom (), with exclusion of the Sanskrit stanza. A slightly improved reading, again only of the Old Malay text, was presented by Damais (). Edited here, for the first time with inclusion of the Sanskrit stanza, by Arlo Griffiths (2026) after direct inspection of the stone at the Nasional Museum of Indonesia and using photogrammetries by Garin Pharmasetiawan and Hedwi Prihatmoko.
